Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowledge of the cold plasma mass density is critically important for a number of magnetospheric studies in the inner magnetosphere. For instance models of the mass density are important for radiation belt research, magnetohydrodynamic models of the solar wind and magnetosphere interaction and Ultra Low Frequency wave research. This is a very difficult quantity to observe directly so an indirect approach will be used. This approach makes use of Alfv√©n wave resonances. The research will expand on previous determinations of the mass density by extending the results closer to the Earth (L~2) and providing a 3D model. The resulting density model will be parameterized by location, solar wind and geomagnetic conditions. This improvement in our knowledge of the mass density will result because of new data from the THEMIS mission.

The strength of this proposal is that it will address a great need for mass density models that extends beyond the present study. If the only accomplishment of this study is expanded radial coverage of the density models it will be a success and that is highly probable.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrical currents within the surface of the Earth create a magnetic field surrounding the Earth. That magnetic field shelters the Earth from the magnetic field and particles coming from the Sun. The magnetosphere is the region of space surrounding the Earth in which the Earth's magnetic field is dominant. Magnetospheric mass density, due to magnetospheric particles such as hydrogen and oxygen, is important because it controls various kinds of waves that can affect the radiation belts, which is composed of charged particles that are dangerous for spacecraft and astronauts. In this investigation, we studied the distribution of mass density, especially at geostationary orbit, that location around the Earth that can rotate with the Earth. We studied the conditions under which the mass density is large. The primary cause of increased mass density is high extreme ultraviolet radiation from the Sun and high geomagnetic activity, related to fluctuations in the magnetic field at the Earth. These conditions lead to greater upflow of oxygen ions from the Earth's ionosphere, which is a thin region with many charged particles above the atmosphere. Another cause of increased mass density relates to location. The mass density increases on the daylight side of the earth toward dusk because charged particles tend to rotate with the earth eastward toward dusk and other particles can come up the magnetic field lines from the ionosphere leading to an increase in density, called refilling. We also studied the distribution of mass density along magnetic field lines and the Alfven waves that can be used to measure mass density. And we developed a new technique for imaging magnetospheric oxygen ions, which contribute dominantly to mass density.
